author: wired blogs
text: all letters refer to the article "a matter of (wired news) style," oct. 23, 2000. date: monday, october 23, 2000 1:02 pmfrom: chip bayers (mailto:chip@wired.com)to: newsfeedback@wired.comsubject: a matter of (wired news) stylejust wanted to let you know that your parody of a 1996 erarant about louis rossetto, constance hale, and all things wiredawakened in me a nostalgia for the days when the most vociferouswired critics were marked by both their pomposity and their completeignorance of the company's inner workings and history. as a founderof wired news, i was particularly amused by your ability to capturethe hectoring, condescending tone of those critics in nearly everysentence of today's essay. the part where you described us as sittingin rapt attention at the feet of our guru, louis, is but onepriceless example. it was as if you were channelling gary chapman.i'm doubly impressed by your ability to capture that tone since idon't recall seeing you around the joint in those days.but i would think the audience for such parodies is limited to those of us who were there. sure, we'll get a chuckle with our memories of the original attacks, but i'm a bit concerned that some people are going to be believe your farcical version is an actual history. is there any concern down there that wired news readers aren't going to get the joke?chip bayers is a former executive producer at wired news.
